claim: Most middle class families have butlers.

supporting.text: Butlers are historically associated with wealthy or aristocratic households, not middle-class families.

attacks.text: Butlers are historically associated with wealthy or aristocratic households, not middle-class families.
Modern middle-class families increasingly employ domestic staff, including butlers, due to rising disposable incomes.
Even with rising incomes, butlers remain a luxury service primarily affordable only to the upper class, not the majority of middle-class families.
In some cultures, butlers or similar domestic roles are more common among middle-class families due to differing labor costs and social norms.
Even in such cultures, the term 'butler' is often misapplied to general domestic helpers, not the traditional butler role associated with wealth.

supporting.text: The cost of hiring a butler is prohibitively expensive for most middle-class families due to salaries and associated employment costs.

attacks.text: The cost of hiring a butler is prohibitively expensive for most middle-class families due to salaries and associated employment costs.
Some middle-class families may inherit or share butlers through multi-generational households or extended family arrangements, reducing individual costs.
Inherited or shared butler arrangements are statistically rare and do not significantly impact the general affordability for most middle-class families.
In certain countries with lower labor costs, middle-class families may afford butlers more easily than in high-income nations.
Even in lower labor-cost countries, butlers remain a luxury service typically reserved for upper-class households due to cultural and economic norms.

supporting.text: Modern middle-class lifestyles typically do not include the need for a butler, as household tasks are often managed by family members or occasional hired help.

attacks.text: Modern middle-class lifestyles typically do not include the need for a butler, as household tasks are often managed by family members or occasional hired help.
In some high-income middle-class households, especially in certain cultures, butlers or domestic staff are still employed for convenience and status.
Even in high-income middle-class households, the employment of butlers remains rare compared to historical norms, as automation and service apps reduce the need for full-time domestic staff.
The definition of 'middle class' varies globally, and in some countries, butlers are more common among middle-class families due to lower labor costs.
Even in countries with lower labor costs, the term 'butler' is often misapplied to general domestic helpers, who perform broader tasks than traditional butler roles.

supporting.text: Statistical data on household employment does not show a significant prevalence of butlers in middle-class homes.

attacks.text: Statistical data on household employment does not show a significant prevalence of butlers in middle-class homes.
Some middle-class families in affluent regions may employ butlers, skewing local statistics.
Even in affluent regions, butlers are rare among middle-class families due to high costs and cultural norms favoring other domestic help.
Historical data shows that butlers were more common in middle-class households in the past, which might influence perceptions.
Modern economic conditions and changing social structures have made butlers largely obsolete for the middle class.

supporting.text: Cultural norms in most societies do not associate butlers with middle-class status, further reducing the likelihood of such employment.

attacks.text: Cultural norms in most societies do not associate butlers with middle-class status, further reducing the likelihood of such employment.
In some affluent societies, middle-class families may employ domestic help, including butlers, as a status symbol.
Even in affluent societies, the cost of employing a full-time butler is typically beyond the means of middle-class families.
Historical data shows that butlers were traditionally employed by upper-class households, not middle-class families.
Modern trends show a decline in traditional butler roles, making them even less common among middle-class families today.
